node.title: Vaccine mandate to be expanded 'to protect vulnerable Queenslanders'
node.alt: Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk addresses PCR test controversy
node.description: Queensland will mandate COVID-19 vaccines for all staff at state and private schools, childcare centres, correctional facilities and airports, Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk says.
node.content:
["Queensland will mandate COVID-19 vaccines for all workers\u00a0in state and private schools, childcare centres, correctional facilities and airports.", "Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk announced all staff\u00a0must have had at least one dose of a vaccine by December 17 and must be fully vaccinated by January 23 \u2013 before the start of the 2022\u00a0school year.", "\"We are taking this strong action to protect vulnerable Queenslanders,\" Ms Palaszczuk told parliament.", "\"It is action that is consistent with other states and territories such as New South Wales and Victoria.", "\"Children under 12 cannot access the vaccination and \u2026 we want to do everything we can to protect these young people.\"", "Police Minister Mark Ryan told state parliament Surf Lifesaving Queensland had\u00a0mandated vaccinations for all volunteers and staff 16 years and over by March, 2022.", "The Queensland government has already mandated the jab for health, aged and disability care staff as well as police, hospitality workers and truck drivers entering the state.", "Tasmania was now the only jurisdiction yet to extend a\u00a0vaccination mandate to the education sector.", "Education Minister Grace Grace told parliament her department will brief unions and independent Catholic and early childhood sector representatives on the incoming mandate this afternoon.", "\"We have a responsibility to protect the more than 500,000 children under 12 in Queensland schools, and even more in early childhood centres, who can't yet get vaccinated,\" Ms Grace said.", "Meanwhile, Queensland recorded no new community cases of COVID-19 but two cases were detected in hotel quarantine in two travellers from Melbourne.", "The Premier said 86.27 per cent of Queenslanders over the age of 16 have now had their first dose of a COVID-19 vaccine and 76.08 per cent were fully vaccinated.", "
No changes to border plans for now despite\u00a0Omicron concern
", "Ms Palaszczuk said plans to ease Queensland's border restrictions next month were unchanged, despite concerns over the new\u00a0COVID-19 variant Omicron.", "\"Our plans to allow quarantine-free interstate travel for fully vaccinated people have not been affected,\" Ms Palaszczuk said.", "\"Queensland is in such a strong position because we still require 14 days' hotel quarantine for international arrivals.", "\"Our cautious and measured approach means anyone who has recently arrived from countries where [the variant] is circulating is already in hotel quarantine in Queensland.\"", "Ms Palaszczuk said she expected to receive the most up-to-date\u00a0information about the new strain at a National Cabinet meeting this afternoon."]
